cookies.title: Everybody loves cookies! (until they follow you) üç™
cookies.lede: Not the chocolate-chip kind. Cookies are tiny text crumbs your browser saves so sites can remember things about you. Handy‚Ä¶ and also a little clingy.
cookies.firstParty: First-party cookies: set by the site you're on ‚Äî logins, carts, "remember me," that sort of useful stuff.
cookies.thirdParty: Third-party cookies: set by outsiders embedded on the page (ad networks, social widgets, analytics). That's how the same folks can spot you across many sites.
cookies.sessionPersistent: Session vs. persistent: session cookies vanish when you close the tab; persistent cookies stick around for days or months, like glitter after a craft accident.
cookies.retargTitle: Retargeting in 4 steps (aka "why am I seeing those exact shoes?")
cookies.retargStep1: You check out Product X on Site A. A tiny "ad pixel" from AdCo loads.
cookies.retargStep2: AdCo drops a third‚Äëparty cookie: "User looked at Product X."
cookies.retargStep3: Later on Site B (also running AdCo), your browser presents that cookie to AdCo.
cookies.retargStep4: AdCo recognizes you and serves an ad for Product X everywhere, forever. Or at least until the cookie expires.
cookies.note: Note: Many browsers now block third-party cookies by default. Retargeting still happens via newer tricks (first-party tracking, server-side stitching, hashed emails). The game evolves.

abTesting.title: A/B Testing: stop guessing, start splitting
abTesting.lede: Marketing opinions are free. Evidence is expensive. Here's the cheap version:
points: Pick one thing to mess with: headline, button text, price anchoring, whatever.
Randomly show A or B to visitors. No peeking at the results "just to check."
Measure one clear metric (clicks, signups, buys). Not "feelings."
Let it run long enough to matter. "We got 12 clicks" is not a conclusion.
Winner goes live. Loser goes to the big archive in the sky.
abTesting.note: Serious A/B requires tooling or backend logic. This is your heads-up that "best practices" are just hypotheses with a good PR team.
